Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: South Pole Ice Core Chronology and Climate Records using Chemical and Microparticle Measurements
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project explores the signatures and causes of natural climate change in the region surrounding Antarctica over the last 40,000 years as the Earth transitioned from an ice age into the modern warm period. The researchers will investigate how the wind belts that surround Antarctica changed in their strength and position through time, and document explosive volcanic eruptions and CO2 cycling in the Southern Ocean as potential climate forcing mechanisms over this interval. Understanding how and why the climate varied naturally in the past is critical for improving understanding of modern climate change and projections of future climate under higher levels of atmospheric CO2.

The investigators plan to conduct a suite of chemical measurements along the 1500m length of the South Pole Ice Core, including major ion and trace element concentrations, and microparticle (dust) concentrations and size distributions. These measurements will (1) extend the South Pole record of explosive volcanic eruptions to 40,000 years using sulfate and particle data; (2) establish the relative timing of climate changes in dust source regions of Patagonia, New Zealand, and Australia using dust flux data; (3) investigate changes in the strength and position of the westerly wind belt using dust size distribution data; and (4) quantify the flux of bioavailable trace metals deposited as dust to the Southern Ocean over time. These chemistry records will also be critical for creating the timescale that will be used by all researchers studying records from the South Pole core. The project will support four graduate students and several undergraduate students across three different institutions, and become a focus of the investigators' efforts to disseminate outcomes of climate change science to the broader community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: Ice core records from Antarctica provide foundational information for understanding natural changes of global climate.  The U.S. ice core science community collected a new 1751 meter-long South Pole Ice core (SPICEcore) in 2014-2016, representing a climate history spanning from 54,302 years ago to present. This 3-year project successfully collected continuous chemistry measurements (major ion and trace element concentrations, and microparticle concentrations and size distribution) at very high resolution (3 mm to 2 cm) along the entire length of the SPICEcore using state-of-the-art ice core melter and discrete sampling techniques. The scientific objectives of this project were to improve understanding of the volcanic, atmospheric circulation, and nutrient deposition history of Antarctica, specifically:

1)    Extending the South Pole record of explosive volcanism from 2,000 to 54,000 years ago by measuring high-resolution sulfate and microparticle concentrations through the entire core.  Volcanic eruptions are important natural causes of climate change and the South Pole has ideal conditions for recording global volcanic events because of its relatively high snowfall rate and strong funneling of volcanic emissions from the stratosphere to the glacier surface. The outstanding volcanic record was an essential component of the SPICEcore timescale developed as part of this project and used by all other SPICEcore research groups.

2)    Establishing the magnitude and timing of climate change in dust source regions such as Patagonia and Australia over the past 54,000 years by developing a record of South Pole dust flux based on calcium and microparticle concentrations. We have found that large, natural swings in climate during the last ice age (known as Stadial-Interstadial Events and Heinrich Events) have distinctive dust records that correspond with changes in Antarctic temperature and atmospheric CO2 concentrations measured in Antarctic ice cores. The SPICEcore record is providing insights into how these dramatic climate warming and cooling events are triggered and prorogate from one pole to the other.

3)    Evaluating changes in the strength and position of the Southern Westerly Winds (SWW) over the past 54,000 years by developing a record of South Pole dust size distribution using continuous laser particle analyses.  The SWW are a dominant climatological feature of the high-latitude Southern Hemisphere that varies in strength and latitudinal position in concert with changes in global climate. The SPICEcore dust and chemistry record shows that the SWW responded differently to cold Stadial events of different magnitude, providing evidence of different triggering mechanisms.

4)    Quantifying the depositional record of trace nutrients (e.g. Fe, Cu) to the Southern Ocean to improve estimations of carbon transfer from the atmosphere to the deep ocean during Stadial-Interstadial Events and during the end of the last ice age.

 

Broader impacts:  The results of this project will improve future projections of Antarctic and Southern Hemisphere climate change and the response of the Antarctic ice sheet - a pressing societal concern as a potential major contributor to sea-level rise. This project focuses on understanding the interactions between atmospheric CO2, air temperature, and deep-ocean currents (so-called 'thermohaline circulation') during times of rapid climate change. The project results therefore provide important constraints on projections of future global climate change, which generally include a slow-down of thermohaline circulation in response to the rapid rise in anthropogenic CO2. The project was also an outstanding vehicle for training the next generation of climate researchers at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels. A total of 28 undergraduate students, 10 graduate students and 1 postdoctoral researcher contributed to aspects of this project, including drilling the ice core in Antarctica, precisely melting and chemically analyzing the ice core in our laboratories, and interpreting and publishing its climate records. Many of these students are women and/or underrepresented minorities. The PIs also actively participated in programs to increase diversity in the Earth Sciences, such as the NSF-sponsored 'School of Ice' program where faculty from minority-serving institutions and historically black colleges and universities learn about glacier and climate research. The research from this project has been disseminated to the scientific community and the public through peer-reviewed publications, conference abstracts and presentations, and distribution of the ice core datasets.
